elements.content: In this study, a water stable metal–organic framework FIR-53 is applied as a single-crystal container for anion exchange. The exceptional chemical stability and low crystallographic symmetry of FIR-53 makes it possible to determine anionic guests. Through ion exchange and single-crystal to single-crystal (SC–SC) transformation, 8-hydroxypyrene-1,3,6-trisulfonate (SG7, solvent green 7, ion form as SG73–) is introduced into the pores of FIR-53 to obtain SG7@FIR-53. Because of the spatial confinement and partition effect, SG7@FIR-53 shows the bright exciter emission of SG7 ions. Interestingly, the composite SG7@FIR-53 exhibits a sensitive fluorescence quenching response against Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 – in aqueous solution. Especially, the detection limit toward MnO4 – is as low as 0.12 ppb, which is the smallest value to date. Moreover, the prepared SG7@FIR-53 film also displays a broad response to nitro explosives in vapor/aqueous phase. Compared with the results of FIR-53, the range and sensitivity were greatly improved.
elements.clean_text: In this study, a water stable metal-organic framework FIR-53 is applied as a single-crystal container for anion exchange. The exceptional chemical stability and low crystallographic symmetry of FIR-53 makes it possible to determine anionic guests. Through ion exchange and single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation, 8-hydroxypyrene-1,3,6-trisulfonate (SG7, solvent green 7, ion form as SG73-) is introduced into the pores of FIR-53 to obtain SG7@FIR-53. Because of the spatial confinement and partition effect, SG7@FIR-53 shows the bright exciter emission of SG7 ions. Interestingly, the composite SG7@FIR-53 exhibits a sensitive fluorescence quenching response against Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 - in aqueous solution. Especially, the detection limit toward MnO4 - is as low as 0.12 ppb, which is the smallest value to date. Moreover, the prepared SG7@FIR-53 film also displays a broad response to nitro explosives in vapor/aqueous phase. Compared with the results of FIR-53, the range and sensitivity were greatly improved.

elements.content: The detection of nitro explosives is of great significance for national security, terrorism, and environmental pollution. Similarly, the sensing of toxic metals and their soluble anions, such as MnO4 – and Cr2O7 2–, play a critical role in environmental monitoring. Fluorescent chemosensors have advantages in terms of sensitivity, selectivity, simplicity, and particularly the multiple readout signals (e.g., spectrum shift, fluorescence intensity, intensity ratio, etc.). Given this, considerable efforts have been devoted to the development of a probe for the detection of nitro explosives and metal ions. Nevertheless, it remains an urgent challenge to explore new materials that could improve the selectivity and sensitivity of detection in the aqueous and vapor phase due to the low solubility of nitro explosives in aqueous solution and low pressure. Also, it is necessary to improve the detection range of nitro explosives on a wide scale. Moreover, it’s also necessary to detect the trace toxic ions at a low concentration in the water medium.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The detection of nitro explosives is of great significance for national security, terrorism, and environmental pollution. Similarly, the sensing of toxic metals and their soluble anions, such as MnO4 - and Cr2O7 2-, play a critical role in environmental monitoring. Fluorescent chemosensors have advantages in terms of sensitivity, selectivity, simplicity, and particularly the multiple readout signals (e.g., spectrum shift, fluorescence intensity, intensity ratio, etc.). Given this, considerable efforts have been devoted to the development of a probe for the detection of nitro explosives and metal ions. Nevertheless, it remains an urgent challenge to explore new materials that could improve the selectivity and sensitivity of detection in the aqueous and vapor phase due to the low solubility of nitro explosives in aqueous solution and low pressure. Also, it is necessary to improve the detection range of nitro explosives on a wide scale. Moreover, it's also necessary to detect the trace toxic ions at a low concentration in the water medium.

elements.content: Pyrene with its high quantum yield and chemical stability has been widely used for fluorescence sensing. However, as a typical molecule for the aggregation-caused quenching effect, pyrene has no fluorescence in the solid state. There are two strategies to realize a strong fluorescence emission: dissolving in solution and dispersing in solid state with certain support. In theory, whether in solution or solid state, the emission of pyrene has two cases: the monomer emission of pyrene means the distance between molecules is longer than 10 Å, and the distance in excimer state is shorter than 10 Å. Excimers are dimeric species that are associated in an excited electronic state but dissociated in their ground electronic state. Also, excimer emission typically shows a broad absorption feature with a large full width at half-maximum, which is desirable to detect various classes of chemicals, including gases, organic molecules, and metal ions. In particular, the excimer emission of pyrene molecules can be used to detect nitro explosives on the basis of interactions between electron-donating molecules and electron-deficient nitro compounds. Nevertheless, this wavelength of excimer emission depends on the molecular interactions and molecular packing structure; it is still a great challenge to control and stabilize the molecular packing structure so as to optimize excimer formation.
elements.clean_text: Pyrene with its high quantum yield and chemical stability has been widely used for fluorescence sensing. However, as a typical molecule for the aggregation-caused quenching effect, pyrene has no fluorescence in the solid state. There are two strategies to realize a strong fluorescence emission: dissolving in solution and dispersing in solid state with certain support. In theory, whether in solution or solid state, the emission of pyrene has two cases: the monomer emission of pyrene means the distance between molecules is longer than 10 Å, and the distance in excimer state is shorter than 10 Å. Excimers are dimeric species that are associated in an excited electronic state but dissociated in their ground electronic state. Also, excimer emission typically shows a broad absorption feature with a large full width at half-maximum, which is desirable to detect various classes of chemicals, including gases, organic molecules, and metal ions. In particular, the excimer emission of pyrene molecules can be used to detect nitro explosives on the basis of interactions between electron-donating molecules and electron-deficient nitro compounds. Nevertheless, this wavelength of excimer emission depends on the molecular interactions and molecular packing structure; it is still a great challenge to control and stabilize the molecular packing structure so as to optimize excimer formation.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as a relative new class of porous materials, have aroused considerable attention. Luminescent MOFs have several key advantages over other potential luminescent materials. Luminescent behaviors of MOFs can be adjusted due to the various options of organic ligands and metal nodes, as well as due to structural diversity, especially MOFs with high porosity, high volume, and large window can also encapsulate the guest chromophores to construct the host–guest luminescent system. Importantly, the inherent crystallinity of metal–organic frameworks can supply the precise structure, even including the structure of guests by single crystal X-ray diffraction, as it allows for the visualization of the molecular arrangement at the atomic scale. The robust frameworks featuring the open window and high volume provide a new platform to obtain the excimer type of pyrene.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as a relative new class of porous materials, have aroused considerable attention. Luminescent MOFs have several key advantages over other potential luminescent materials. Luminescent behaviors of MOFs can be adjusted due to the various options of organic ligands and metal nodes, as well as due to structural diversity, especially MOFs with high porosity, high volume, and large window can also encapsulate the guest chromophores to construct the host-guest luminescent system. Importantly, the inherent crystallinity of metal-organic frameworks can supply the precise structure, even including the structure of guests by single crystal X-ray diffraction, as it allows for the visualization of the molecular arrangement at the atomic scale. The robust frameworks featuring the open window and high volume provide a new platform to obtain the excimer type of pyrene.

elements.content: Herein, a water stable metal–organic framework FIR-53 is applied as single-crystal container to realize the bright exciter emission of pyrene. Through ion exchange and single-crystal to single-crystal (SC–SC) transformation, the derivative of pyrene, 8-hydroxypyrene-1,3,6-trisulfonate, (SG7, solvent green 7, ion form as SG73–) is introduced into the pores of FIR-53 to obtain SG7@FIR-53, which shows the bright exciter emission of SG7 ions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example where metal–organic framework immobilizing dye ions could obtain the single-crystal structure of a host–guest system. Interestingly, the composite SG7@FIR-53 exhibits the sensitive fluorescence quenching response against Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 – in solution. Especially, the detection limit toward MnO4 – is as low as 0.12 ppb, which is the smallest value to date. More importantly, the prepared SG7@FIR-53 film displays a broad response to nitro explosives in vapor/aqueous phase. Compared with the results of FIR-53, the range and sensitivity was greatly improved. On the whole, these results demonstrate that luminescent SG7@FIR-53 presents a promising multiresponsive sensing platform.
elements.clean_text: Herein, a water stable metal-organic framework FIR-53 is applied as single-crystal container to realize the bright exciter emission of pyrene. Through ion exchange and single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation, the derivative of pyrene, 8-hydroxypyrene-1,3,6-trisulfonate, (SG7, solvent green 7, ion form as SG73-) is introduced into the pores of FIR-53 to obtain SG7@FIR-53, which shows the bright exciter emission of SG7 ions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example where metal-organic framework immobilizing dye ions could obtain the single-crystal structure of a host-guest system. Interestingly, the composite SG7@FIR-53 exhibits the sensitive fluorescence quenching response against Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 - in solution. Especially, the detection limit toward MnO4 - is as low as 0.12 ppb, which is the smallest value to date. More importantly, the prepared SG7@FIR-53 film displays a broad response to nitro explosives in vapor/aqueous phase. Compared with the results of FIR-53, the range and sensitivity was greatly improved. On the whole, these results demonstrate that luminescent SG7@FIR-53 presents a promising multiresponsive sensing platform.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents used in this work were commercially available. Tipa was prepared by literature methods. Deionized water was used as solvent in this work. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis has been determined on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermal analysis was performed by the NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under air atmosphere. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) adsorption spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer. The luminescent measurements were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 Fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Instrumentation

All reagents and solvents used in this work were commercially available. Tipa was prepared by literature methods. Deionized water was used as solvent in this work. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis has been determined on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermal analysis was performed by the NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under air atmosphere. Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) adsorption spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer. The luminescent measurements were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 Fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: The diffraction data were measured at 100 K under nitrogen flow with a Rigaku Supernova CCD system equipped with confocal monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). All structures were solved by a direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares using SHELX-2014. The structure was solved with XS structure solution program and refined with XL refinement package using least-squares minimization. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. All hydrogen atoms were located on geometrically ideal positions and refined using a riding model. The contribution of the missing solvent molecule and other ionic residues to the diffraction patterns was subtracted from the reflection data by the SQUEEZE method, as implemented in PLATON. CCDC number is 1545250. The data detail of SG7@FIR-53 is listed in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

The diffraction data were measured at 100 K under nitrogen flow with a Rigaku Supernova CCD system equipped with confocal monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All structures were solved by a direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares using SHELX-2014. The structure was solved with XS structure solution program and refined with XL refinement package using least-squares minimization. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. All hydrogen atoms were located on geometrically ideal positions and refined using a riding model. The contribution of the missing solvent molecule and other ionic residues to the diffraction patterns was subtracted from the reflection data by the SQUEEZE method, as implemented in PLATON. CCDC number is 1545250. The data detail of SG7@FIR-53 is listed in Table S1.

elements.content:
The crystal sample [Zn2(tipa)2(OH–)]­(NO3 –)3·6H2O was synthesized according to the reported literature.

Preparation of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(tipa)<sub>2</sub>(OH<sup>–</sup>)]­(NO<sub>3</sub> <sup>–</sup>)­(SG7)<sub>2/3</sub>·5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>SG7@FIR-53</bold>)

The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (30 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 8 mL, 4 × 10–3 mol L–1 solution of SG7 and kept for 1 month. The vials were shaken once a day. The dye-nitrate exchange process was monitored by UV–vis abosrption; the value of UV–vis abosrption remained unchanged when the process reached the dynamic equilibrium. After decanting the solution, the green-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air. EA, calcd for C62H55N15O15S2Zn2: C, 53.15; H, 3.80; N, 14.53%; found: C, 52.96; H, 4.01; N, 14.07%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn2(tipa)2(OH-)](NO3 -)3⋅6H2O (FIR-53)

The crystal sample [Zn2(tipa)2(OH-)](NO3 -)3⋅6H2O was synthesized according to the reported literature. 

Preparation of [Zn2(tipa)2(OH-)](NO3 -)(SG7)2/3⋅5H2O (SG7@FIR-53)

The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (30 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 8 mL, 4 × 10-3 mol L-1 solution of SG7 and kept for 1 month. The vials were shaken once a day. The dye-nitrate exchange process was monitored by UV-vis abosrption; the value of UV-vis abosrption remained unchanged when the process reached the dynamic equilibrium. After decanting the solution, the green-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air. EA, calcd for C62H55N15O15S2Zn2: C, 53.15; H, 3.80; N, 14.53%; found: C, 52.96; H, 4.01; N, 14.07%.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of SG7@FIR-53 were examined in the solid state, in organic solvent suspensions, and in vapors at room temperature. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Prior to the measurements, the as-synthesized sample of FIR-53 was immersed into anhydrous methanol for 3 days; methanol was refreshed three times during the exchange. The wet sample was dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h to yield activated sample. The activated solid samples of SG7@FIR-53 were ground into powder and used for measurements. The details are as follows.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence-Sensing Methodology

The luminescent properties of SG7@FIR-53 were examined in the solid state, in organic solvent suspensions, and in vapors at room temperature. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Prior to the measurements, the as-synthesized sample of FIR-53 was immersed into anhydrous methanol for 3 days; methanol was refreshed three times during the exchange. The wet sample was dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h to yield activated sample. The activated solid samples of SG7@FIR-53 were ground into powder and used for measurements. The details are as follows.

elements.content: The luminescent spectra of SG7@FIR-53 treated by containing different heavy anion aqueous solutions were studied (SO4 2–, NO3 –, Br–, VO4 3–, Cl–, F–, I–, SCN–, Cr2O7 2–, CH3COO– (OAc–), C2O4 2– (OX2–); the concentration of each ion is 1.0 × 10–3 M). The standard suspensions were prepared by adding the ground sample (2 mg) into metal-ion aqueous solution with the same concentration (2 mL) and then treated by ultrasonication for 30 min. The quenching efficiency is defined by (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of the sensor before and after the addition of analytes, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Anion-Sensing Measure

The luminescent spectra of SG7@FIR-53 treated by containing different heavy anion aqueous solutions were studied (SO4 2-, NO3 -, Br-, VO4 3-, Cl-, F-, I-, SCN-, Cr2O7 2-, CH3COO- (OAc-), C2O4 2- (OX2-); the concentration of each ion is 1.0 × 10-3 M). The standard suspensions were prepared by adding the ground sample (2 mg) into metal-ion aqueous solution with the same concentration (2 mL) and then treated by ultrasonication for 30 min. The quenching efficiency is defined by (I 0 - I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of the sensor before and after the addition of analytes, respectively.

elements.content: The sample used as an in situ time-dependent photoluminescence sensor for solvent vapors was prepared as follows. The ground sample of SG7@FIR-53 was pressed into a firm sheet, which was attached to a quartz slide and placed into a cuvette, and the sample was kept about 0.3 cm away from the bottom. First, the solid-state emission spectra of the firm sheet sample were recorded as an initial standard; then, 0.2 mL or 10 mg of detectors was carefully added into the cuvette and sealed as soon as possible. The below nitro explosives were chosen as analytes: nitrobenzene (NB), 2-nitrotoluene (2-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), 3-nitrophenol (3-NP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), as well as toluene, nitromethane, acetone, acetonitrile, methanol, ethanol, 4-dioxane, 2-propanol, phenylmethanol, and water.
elements.clean_text:
Vapor-Phase Detection Measure

The sample used as an in situ time-dependent photoluminescence sensor for solvent vapors was prepared as follows. The ground sample of SG7@FIR-53 was pressed into a firm sheet, which was attached to a quartz slide and placed into a cuvette, and the sample was kept about 0.3 cm away from the bottom. First, the solid-state emission spectra of the firm sheet sample were recorded as an initial standard; then, 0.2 mL or 10 mg of detectors was carefully added into the cuvette and sealed as soon as possible. The below nitro explosives were chosen as analytes: nitrobenzene (NB), 2-nitrotoluene (2-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), 3-nitrophenol (3-NP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), as well as toluene, nitromethane, acetone, acetonitrile, methanol, ethanol, 4-dioxane, 2-propanol, phenylmethanol, and water.

elements.content: The finely ground sample powders dispersed in 2 mL of aqueous solutions of a series of analytes were subjected to ultrasonication for 0.5 h and then aged to form a stable emulsion for the measurements. All titration tests were carried out by gradually adding solutions of analytes into the water suspension of the two samples.
elements.clean_text:
Aqueous-Phase Detection Measure

The finely ground sample powders dispersed in 2 mL of aqueous solutions of a series of analytes were subjected to ultrasonication for 0.5 h and then aged to form a stable emulsion for the measurements. All titration tests were carried out by gradually adding solutions of analytes into the water suspension of the two samples.

elements.content: FIR-53 has been reported by us before, for better understanding host–guest interactions and relations; the structure features are briefly discussed here. In FIR-53, each Zn2+ ion is four-coordinated by three N atoms from three tipa ligands and one OH–. Each tipa ligand connects three Zn2+ ions to form a two-dimensional (2D) layer with three-connected network (Figure S1a,c). Then, two adjacent layers are connected together via μ2-OH– anions to form a bilayer structure. Moreover, 2D bilayers are parallel to each other and pack in ABAB mode to give rise to a three-dimensional (3D) network (Figure S1b,d), which is stabilized by π–π interactions. FIR-53 owns two kinds of one-dimensional ellipse channels along the c axis: the large one is the eight-ring with window sizes of ca. 19.8 × 14 Å2, whereas the small one is the four-ring with window sizes of ca. 4.4 × 5.2 Å2 (taking the van der Waals radii of the relative atoms into consideration), respectively, which were filled by order NO3 – counterions as well as disordered guest molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

FIR-53 has been reported by us before, for better understanding host-guest interactions and relations; the structure features are briefly discussed here. In FIR-53, each Zn2+ ion is four-coordinated by three N atoms from three tipa ligands and one OH-. Each tipa ligand connects three Zn2+ ions to form a two-dimensional (2D) layer with three-connected network (Figure S1a,c). Then, two adjacent layers are connected together via μ2-OH- anions to form a bilayer structure. Moreover, 2D bilayers are parallel to each other and pack in ABAB mode to give rise to a three-dimensional (3D) network (Figure S1b,d), which is stabilized by π-π interactions. FIR-53 owns two kinds of one-dimensional ellipse channels along the c axis: the large one is the eight-ring with window sizes of ca. 19.8 × 14 Å2, whereas the small one is the four-ring with window sizes of ca. 4.4 × 5.2 Å2 (taking the van der Waals radii of the relative atoms into consideration), respectively, which were filled by order NO3 - counterions as well as disordered guest molecules.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that FIR-53 has high chemical stability. Actually, it still can obtain the structure by single-crystal X-ray diffraction in air or water over 1 year. Such unusual stability in combination with the low symmetry of the framework benefits as a systematic platform for ion exchange through a single-crystal to single-crystal pattern.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that FIR-53 has high chemical stability. Actually, it still can obtain the structure by single-crystal X-ray diffraction in air or water over 1 year. Such unusual stability in combination with the low symmetry of the framework benefits as a systematic platform for ion exchange through a single-crystal to single-crystal pattern.

elements.content: FIR-53 combines the three advantages: (i) the large channels of the framework supply the convenient passage for the diffusion of guests; (ii) the high stability can guarantee the long-lasting durability; (iii) the high charge of the counterions in each cell is in favor of trapping much more guests with the opposite charge. On the whole, FIR-53 can serve as a perfect host platform for loading functional ions via the ion-exchange approach.
elements.clean_text: FIR-53 combines the three advantages: (i) the large channels of the framework supply the convenient passage for the diffusion of guests; (ii) the high stability can guarantee the long-lasting durability; (iii) the high charge of the counterions in each cell is in favor of trapping much more guests with the opposite charge. On the whole, FIR-53 can serve as a perfect host platform for loading functional ions via the ion-exchange approach.

elements.content: On the basis of the above consideration, the derivative of pyrene, 8-hydroxypyrene-1,3,6-trisulfonate, (SG7, solvent green 7, ion form as SG73–) is selected as the model; in theory, SG73– could enter into the channel by considering that the kinetic size of SG73– is smaller than the window size of FIR-53.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above consideration, the derivative of pyrene, 8-hydroxypyrene-1,3,6-trisulfonate, (SG7, solvent green 7, ion form as SG73-) is selected as the model; in theory, SG73- could enter into the channel by considering that the kinetic size of SG73- is smaller than the window size of FIR-53.

elements.content: FIR-53 crystals were submerged into SG7 aqueous solution at room temperature. The color of crystals gradually turns transparent to yellow green (a,c). As expected, the morphology and crystal state remain unchanged until the exchange behaviors reach a dynamic balance. The structure of FIR-53-immobilized SG73– (SG7@FIR-53) was successfully analyzed via the single-crystal X-ray diffraction pattern. In SG7@FIR-53, SG73– instead of NO3 – as counterions located in the large channels (a). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example where π-conjugated organic small molecules were encapsulated into a metal–organic framework with the specific structure via the SC–SC approach. Meanwhile, it was observed that the overall framework of FIR-53 has changed, leading to a variation of the window scale from 19.8 × 14.4 Å2 in FIR-53 to 20.2 × 17.3 Å2 in SG7@FIR-53 (b,d). Meanwhile, the porosity without consideration of solvent molecules of compound FIR-53 before and after ion exchange was calculated by PLATON; the porosity turns from 39.2% (per unit cell volume/total solvent area volume, 16 145.2/6329.3 Å3) to 34.4% (16 215.3/5575.2 Å3), which suggests that the ion-exchange behaviors implement with the strong host–guest interaction. SG73– anions located on the sides of channels further form a double layer paralleling each other along c-axis and all being perpendicular to the ab plane; the distance of the nearest SG73– ions on both sides of the channels is about 10 Å (b), probably giving rise to the excimer emission of pyrene, meaning that the emission of SG7 aggregation exceeds 470 nm. SG7 ions were introduced into the channels of FIR-53 via SC–SC transformation; however, only NO3 – ions located into larger channels were replaced by SG7 ions. Despite the change of ion-exchange environment, that is, it takes longer time to preform ion exchange, NO3 – ions located into the smaller channels still were not exchanged out.
elements.clean_text: FIR-53 crystals were submerged into SG7 aqueous solution at room temperature. The color of crystals gradually turns transparent to yellow green (a,c). As expected, the morphology and crystal state remain unchanged until the exchange behaviors reach a dynamic balance. The structure of FIR-53-immobilized SG73- (SG7@FIR-53) was successfully analyzed via the single-crystal X-ray diffraction pattern. In SG7@FIR-53, SG73- instead of NO3 - as counterions located in the large channels (a). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example where π-conjugated organic small molecules were encapsulated into a metal-organic framework with the specific structure via the SC-SC approach. Meanwhile, it was observed that the overall framework of FIR-53 has changed, leading to a variation of the window scale from 19.8 × 14.4 Å2 in FIR-53 to 20.2 × 17.3 Å2 in SG7@FIR-53 (b,d). Meanwhile, the porosity without consideration of solvent molecules of compound FIR-53 before and after ion exchange was calculated by PLATON; the porosity turns from 39.2% (per unit cell volume/total solvent area volume, 16145.2/6329.3 Å3) to 34.4% (16215.3/5575.2 Å3), which suggests that the ion-exchange behaviors implement with the strong host-guest interaction. SG73- anions located on the sides of channels further form a double layer paralleling each other along c-axis and all being perpendicular to the ab plane; the distance of the nearest SG73- ions on both sides of the channels is about 10 Å (b), probably giving rise to the excimer emission of pyrene, meaning that the emission of SG7 aggregation exceeds 470 nm. SG7 ions were introduced into the channels of FIR-53 via SC-SC transformation; however, only NO3 - ions located into larger channels were replaced by SG7 ions. Despite the change of ion-exchange environment, that is, it takes longer time to preform ion exchange, NO3 - ions located into the smaller channels still were not exchanged out.

elements.content: (a) Photograph of FIR-53 crystals; (b) 3D framework of FIR-53 along c axis, the windows with dimensions of 19.8 × 14.4 Å2; (c) 3D framework of SG7@FIR-53 along c axis, the windows with dimensions of 20.2 × 17.3 Å2; (d) the photograph of FIR-53 after ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Photograph of FIR-53 crystals; (b) 3D framework of FIR-53 along c axis, the windows with dimensions of 19.8 × 14.4 Å2; (c) 3D framework of SG7@FIR-53 along c axis, the windows with dimensions of 20.2 × 17.3 Å2; (d) the photograph of FIR-53 after ion exchange.

elements.content: (a) Three-dimensional frameworks of FIR-53; (b) 3D frameworks of SG7@FIR-53, SG73– as counterparts into the channels; (c) the arrangement and configuration of SG7 3– along the two sides of the channels; (d) the emission peaks of FIR-53, SG7@FIR-53, free tipa, and SG7 in solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Three-dimensional frameworks of FIR-53; (b) 3D frameworks of SG7@FIR-53, SG73- as counterparts into the channels; (c) the arrangement and configuration of SG7 3- along the two sides of the channels; (d) the emission peaks of FIR-53, SG7@FIR-53, free tipa, and SG7 in solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: To verify this hypothesis, the luminescent spectra of SG7@FIR-53, FIR-53, the free tipa, and SG7 in the solid state were investigated. As expected, the SG7 shows no emission in the solid state, whereas the free tipa ligand and FIR-53 display similar intense and broad emissions in the range from 375 to 470 nm. In comparison, SG7@FIR-53 shows strong green emission and exhibits the dual-emission model at around 375–455 and 500–550 nm under the excitation wavelength at 310 nm. Noticeably, UV–vis adsorption of SG7 shows two main bands between 275–310 and 390–420 nm; there is partial overlapping of the emission peak of tipa, indicating that the inner-filter effect exists between tipa and SG7. So the former band of SG7@FIR-53 can be attributed to the emission of tipa, whereas the latter belongs to the emission of SG7 (d). It is worth noting that the emission peak of SG7 shows an obvious redshift compared with the monomer emission of pyrene (λemission = 375–405 nm). In fact, there are two emission peaks of SG7 at the early stage of ion exchange, the former one between 415 and 450 nm gradually disappears with the development of the ion-exchanged process (Figure S2), suggesting that the pyrene molecules were in close proximity inside the confined channels, which favored formation of the excimer formation. It is clearly indicated that the experimental results on the SG7 aggregation are in good agreement with the theoretical analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of Solid-State Fluorescence

To verify this hypothesis, the luminescent spectra of SG7@FIR-53, FIR-53, the free tipa, and SG7 in the solid state were investigated. As expected, the SG7 shows no emission in the solid state, whereas the free tipa ligand and FIR-53 display similar intense and broad emissions in the range from 375 to 470 nm. In comparison, SG7@FIR-53 shows strong green emission and exhibits the dual-emission model at around 375-455 and 500-550 nm under the excitation wavelength at 310 nm. Noticeably, UV-vis adsorption of SG7 shows two main bands between 275-310 and 390-420 nm; there is partial overlapping of the emission peak of tipa, indicating that the inner-filter effect exists between tipa and SG7. So the former band of SG7@FIR-53 can be attributed to the emission of tipa, whereas the latter belongs to the emission of SG7 (d). It is worth noting that the emission peak of SG7 shows an obvious redshift compared with the monomer emission of pyrene (λemission = 375-405 nm). In fact, there are two emission peaks of SG7 at the early stage of ion exchange, the former one between 415 and 450 nm gradually disappears with the development of the ion-exchanged process (Figure S2), suggesting that the pyrene molecules were in close proximity inside the confined channels, which favored formation of the excimer formation. It is clearly indicated that the experimental results on the SG7 aggregation are in good agreement with the theoretical analysis.

elements.content: Remarkably, SG7@FIR-53 shows excellent and stable fluorescence emission behaviors. The fluorescence intensities have little decay when the composites were kept in air or in aqueous solution for 60 days (Figure S7). It is for sure that nanoporous channels act as geometrical barrier against the dissociation of pyrene aggregation and greatly enhance the excimer formation; even the excimer state can remain stable after solvent molecules escape. These results confirm that SG7@FIR-53 can serve as a robust sensor.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence in the Aqueous Media

Remarkably, SG7@FIR-53 shows excellent and stable fluorescence emission behaviors. The fluorescence intensities have little decay when the composites were kept in air or in aqueous solution for 60 days (Figure S7). It is for sure that nanoporous channels act as geometrical barrier against the dissociation of pyrene aggregation and greatly enhance the excimer formation; even the excimer state can remain stable after solvent molecules escape. These results confirm that SG7@FIR-53 can serve as a robust sensor.

elements.content: Considering its excellent and stable fluorescence properties, SG7@FIR-53 may serve as a guest-promoting chemical sensor. Anion-sensing experiments were carried out to test the potential application of SG7@FIR-53 as the sensor. Compared with the blue emission, the fluorescence intensity of the green emission (the emission of SG7) is not only stronger but also its variation is more distinct. The change of fluorescence intensity of SG7 was selected as a reference. The analytes, such as F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, OAc–, SO4 2–, NO3 –, PMo12O40 3–, PW12O40 3–, VO3–, and SCN–, did not cause a remarkable variation to the fluorescence intensity, whereas Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 – significantly depressed fluorescence intensity (a and S8). This clearly shows that SG7@FIR-53 shows the selective detection of Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 –.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Sensing

Considering its excellent and stable fluorescence properties, SG7@FIR-53 may serve as a guest-promoting chemical sensor. Anion-sensing experiments were carried out to test the potential application of SG7@FIR-53 as the sensor. Compared with the blue emission, the fluorescence intensity of the green emission (the emission of SG7) is not only stronger but also its variation is more distinct. The change of fluorescence intensity of SG7 was selected as a reference. The analytes, such as F-, Cl-, Br-, I-, OAc-, SO4 2-, NO3 -, PMo12O40 3-, PW12O40 3-, VO3-, and SCN-, did not cause a remarkable variation to the fluorescence intensity, whereas Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 - significantly depressed fluorescence intensity (a and S8). This clearly shows that SG7@FIR-53 shows the selective detection of Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 -.

elements.content: (a) Luminescent intensity of SG7@FIR-53 interacting with different anios; (b) emission spectra of SG7@FIR-53 after incremental additions of an aqueous MnO4 – solution.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Luminescent intensity of SG7@FIR-53 interacting with different anios; (b) emission spectra of SG7@FIR-53 after incremental additions of an aqueous MnO4 - solution.

elements.content: To assess the ability of SG7@FIR-53 to sense the trace amounts of Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 – in water, fluorescence titrations were performed. It is obvious that the concentrations of Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 – completely quenching the fluorescence are 20.0 and 2.2 ppm (Figures S9 and S10) and the detection limit calculated by 3σ/k (σ represents the standard deviation for intensity of SG7@FIR-53 in the absence of analytes and k represents the slope of the equation) is as low as 1.02 and 0.12 ppb, respectively (Figures S15 and S16). To the best of our knowledge, SG7@FIR-53 has the lowest detection limit of MnO4 – among the reported MOF-based sensors (Table S3 and S4).
elements.clean_text: To assess the ability of SG7@FIR-53 to sense the trace amounts of Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 - in water, fluorescence titrations were performed. It is obvious that the concentrations of Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 - completely quenching the fluorescence are 20.0 and 2.2 ppm (Figures S9 and S10) and the detection limit calculated by 3σ/k (σ represents the standard deviation for intensity of SG7@FIR-53 in the absence of analytes and k represents the slope of the equation) is as low as 1.02 and 0.12 ppb, respectively (Figures S15 and S16). To the best of our knowledge, SG7@FIR-53 has the lowest detection limit of MnO4 - among the reported MOF-based sensors (Table S3 and S4).

elements.content: Encouraged by its remarkable sensing ability for Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 – anions, the fluorescence test in the presence of other anions was also performed. The emission intensity is greatly quenched with the addition of Cr2O7 2– or MnO4 – ions even in the presence of large amount of other anions (Figures S13 and S14), indicating other anions show little interference to Cr2O7 2– or MnO4 – detection.
elements.clean_text: Encouraged by its remarkable sensing ability for Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 - anions, the fluorescence test in the presence of other anions was also performed. The emission intensity is greatly quenched with the addition of Cr2O7 2- or MnO4 - ions even in the presence of large amount of other anions (Figures S13 and S14), indicating other anions show little interference to Cr2O7 2- or MnO4 - detection.

elements.content: The possible detection mechanism is tentatively analyzed here. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns suggest that the framework remains with integrity during the whole process. However, UV–vis spectra of MnO4 – (480–580 nm) in aqueous solutions almost mantled the emission peak of SG7 (Figure S17, 490–580 nm), indicating that competitive adsorption of excitation energy caused the sharp decrease of fluorescent intensity of SG7@FIR-53, and dominates the quenching behaviors.
elements.clean_text: The possible detection mechanism is tentatively analyzed here. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns suggest that the framework remains with integrity during the whole process. However, UV-vis spectra of MnO4 - (480-580 nm) in aqueous solutions almost mantled the emission peak of SG7 (Figure S17, 490-580 nm), indicating that competitive adsorption of excitation energy caused the sharp decrease of fluorescent intensity of SG7@FIR-53, and dominates the quenching behaviors.

elements.content: To further research its sensing properties, we prepared the SG7@FIR-53 sample solid film for the sake of convenience for detecting the vapor-phase sensing of nitro explosives. As shown in , a and S19–S26, the luminescent emission of SG7@FIR-53-based film exhibits both the characteristic emissions. The fluorescence intensity was immediately recorded after the film was rapidly inserted into the cuvette and the cuvette was sealed. It is evidently observed that the different fluorescence quenchings occur with the decrease of the dual peaks upon response for each analyte. Using the emission of dye SG7 as the reference, the response ability of the composite film against the explosive vapor follows the order NB > 2-NP > 2-NT > 1,3-DNB > 2,4-DNT > 4-NP > TNP > 3-NP. More importantly, the film sensor has a fast response to NB and 2-NP; 64 and 73% quenching efficiencies were observed in as short as 3 min upon exposure to the vapor of NB and 2-NP. Figure S40 shows emission of films after being exposed to NB under UV-light illumination. The obvious fluorescence quenching can be visually observed. Compared with the reported results of a pyrene-dominated vapor sensor, especially the sol–gel materials and dense polymers, SG7@FIR-53 film displays much shorter switching time. It is known that preparation of film materials with the strong excimer emission is challenging due to the loose interaction between pyrene molecules and lack of corresponding support or immobilization. Here, on one hand, benefiting from the spatial confinement of MOF, the double layer consisting of SG could remain stable, on the other hand, because of the large channel, there is still enough space between the bilayers, which enhances the diffusion of nitro-explosive vapor into the internal space and further improves the sensing efficiency.
elements.clean_text:
Vapor-Phase Sensing of Nitro Explosives

To further research its sensing properties, we prepared the SG7@FIR-53 sample solid film for the sake of convenience for detecting the vapor-phase sensing of nitro explosives. As shown in , a and S19-S26, the luminescent emission of SG7@FIR-53-based film exhibits both the characteristic emissions. The fluorescence intensity was immediately recorded after the film was rapidly inserted into the cuvette and the cuvette was sealed. It is evidently observed that the different fluorescence quenchings occur with the decrease of the dual peaks upon response for each analyte. Using the emission of dye SG7 as the reference, the response ability of the composite film against the explosive vapor follows the order NB > 2-NP > 2-NT > 1,3-DNB > 2,4-DNT > 4-NP > TNP > 3-NP. More importantly, the film sensor has a fast response to NB and 2-NP; 64 and 73% quenching efficiencies were observed in as short as 3 min upon exposure to the vapor of NB and 2-NP. Figure S40 shows emission of films after being exposed to NB under UV-light illumination. The obvious fluorescence quenching can be visually observed. Compared with the reported results of a pyrene-dominated vapor sensor, especially the sol-gel materials and dense polymers, SG7@FIR-53 film displays much shorter switching time. It is known that preparation of film materials with the strong excimer emission is challenging due to the loose interaction between pyrene molecules and lack of corresponding support or immobilization. Here, on one hand, benefiting from the spatial confinement of MOF, the double layer consisting of SG could remain stable, on the other hand, because of the large channel, there is still enough space between the bilayers, which enhances the diffusion of nitro-explosive vapor into the internal space and further improves the sensing efficiency.

elements.content: Fluorescence quenching spectra of SG7@FIR-53 film upon exposure to vapors of various nitro aromatic compounds (λex = 290 nm). (a) NB; (b) 2-NP; (c) TNP; and (d) 3-NP.
elements.clean_text: 4  Fluorescence quenching spectra of SG7@FIR-53 film upon exposure to vapors of various nitro aromatic compounds (λex = 290 nm). (a) NB; (b) 2-NP; (c) TNP; and (d) 3-NP.

elements.content: (a) Quenching percentage of SG7@FIR-53 upon exposure to vapors of various nitro explosives; (b) recyclability of SG7@FIR-53 toward NB. Pink column represents fluorescence intensity after the sample film exposure to NB vapor; orange column represents fluorescence intensity after the sample film washed by ethanol and dried in air each time.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Quenching percentage of SG7@FIR-53 upon exposure to vapors of various nitro explosives; (b) recyclability of SG7@FIR-53 toward NB. Pink column represents fluorescence intensity after the sample film exposure to NB vapor; orange column represents fluorescence intensity after the sample film washed by ethanol and dried in air each time.

elements.content: In addition, the selectivity of SG7@FIR-53 film against the common organic solvents was also tested. Exposure of the sensor to methanol, ethanol, phenylcarbinol, dioxane, and acetone did not cause the significant fluorescence quenching (Figures S35–S39). Furthermore, the fluorescence intensity was greatly reduced along with the addition of NB or 2-NT (20 μL) into the mixed solution, i.e., the solution composed by the above organic solvents, indicating the good selectivity toward nitro explosives. Meanwhile, the fluorescence intensity of the film almost did not reduce after the fourth time (b) and PXRD patterns further confirm the durable property of the powder sample, suggesting the good recyclability of SG7@FIR-53-based film system.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the selectivity of SG7@FIR-53 film against the common organic solvents was also tested. Exposure of the sensor to methanol, ethanol, phenylcarbinol, dioxane, and acetone did not cause the significant fluorescence quenching (Figures S35-S39). Furthermore, the fluorescence intensity was greatly reduced along with the addition of NB or 2-NT (20 μL) into the mixed solution, i.e., the solution composed by the above organic solvents, indicating the good selectivity toward nitro explosives. Meanwhile, the fluorescence intensity of the film almost did not reduce after the fourth time (b) and PXRD patterns further confirm the durable property of the powder sample, suggesting the good recyclability of SG7@FIR-53-based film system.

elements.content: To exploit the aqueous-phase detection of nitro explosives, the titration experiments were carried out with the incremental addition of the freshly prepared solutions of nitro analytes into the aqueous suspension of SG7@FIR-53. The order of quenching at the concentration of 100 ppm is: TNP > 2-NT > 4-NP > 2-NP > 1,3-DNB > 3-NP > NB >2,4-DNT (b and S31–S34). Particularly, TNP shows a 71.6% quenching effect at a concentration of 5 ppm and 60.4 and 83.6% quenching is observed for 2-NT at 5 and 20 ppm, respectively. The complete quenching concentration of SG7@FIR-53 toward TNP and 2-NT is as low as 20 and 30 ppm, respectively. These results indicate that compound 1 is one of the top MOF-based sensors for the selective detection of 2-NT and TNP.
elements.clean_text:
Aqueoue-Phase Sensing of Nitro Explosives

To exploit the aqueous-phase detection of nitro explosives, the titration experiments were carried out with the incremental addition of the freshly prepared solutions of nitro analytes into the aqueous suspension of SG7@FIR-53. The order of quenching at the concentration of 100 ppm is: TNP > 2-NT > 4-NP > 2-NP > 1,3-DNB > 3-NP > NB >2,4-DNT (b and S31-S34). Particularly, TNP shows a 71.6% quenching effect at a concentration of 5 ppm and 60.4 and 83.6% quenching is observed for 2-NT at 5 and 20 ppm, respectively. The complete quenching concentration of SG7@FIR-53 toward TNP and 2-NT is as low as 20 and 30 ppm, respectively. These results indicate that compound 1 is one of the top MOF-based sensors for the selective detection of 2-NT and TNP.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence quenching efficiency of FIR-53 toward different analytes; (b) the fluorescence quenching efficiency of SG7@FIR-53 toward different analytes; (c) the comparison of fluorescence quenching efficiency between two compounds when the concentration of nitro explosives is at 20 ppm; (d) the comparison of fluorescence quenching efficiency between two compounds when the concentration of nitro explosives is at 100 ppm.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Fluorescence quenching efficiency of FIR-53 toward different analytes; (b) the fluorescence quenching efficiency of SG7@FIR-53 toward different analytes; (c) the comparison of fluorescence quenching efficiency between two compounds when the concentration of nitro explosives is at 20 ppm; (d) the comparison of fluorescence quenching efficiency between two compounds when the concentration of nitro explosives is at 100 ppm.

elements.content: Meanwhile, the controlled experiments were also performed through only using FIR-53 as sensor. As shown in a and S27–S30, FIR-53 only exhibits the selectivity toward TNP and 2-NT; by contrast, SG7@FIR-53 shows a high response to a broad class of nitro explosives in the range of 20–100 ppm. These results reveal that the introduction of the dye molecule SG7 into the metal–organic framework could not only significantly improve the sensitivity but also enlarge the detection range.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, the controlled experiments were also performed through only using FIR-53 as sensor. As shown in a and S27-S30, FIR-53 only exhibits the selectivity toward TNP and 2-NT; by contrast, SG7@FIR-53 shows a high response to a broad class of nitro explosives in the range of 20-100 ppm. These results reveal that the introduction of the dye molecule SG7 into the metal-organic framework could not only significantly improve the sensitivity but also enlarge the detection range.

elements.content: Compared with the results of FIR-53 in aqueous solution, SG7@FIR-53 shows a better detection effect. It is necessary to gain insights into the mechanism. The introduction of dye SG7 into FIR-53 could enhance the electron transfer from electron donors to analytes. Meanwhile, the existence of resonance energy transfer (RET) was considered by the method of UV–vis absorption. Because of the existence of SG7, the emission band FIR-53 is expanded from 450 to 520 nm. It further enlarges the extent of overlap between the emission spectrum of SG7@FIR-53 and the absorption spectrum of the acceptor (analytes). The absorption spectrum of TNP has a maximum overlap with the emission spectrum of SG7@FIR-53. Especially, 2-NP, 3-NP, and 4-NP have the larger overlap degree of spectra between nitro explosives and SG7@FIR-53 (Figure S42). The fact reveals that the RET may dominate the high sensitivity of SG7@FIR-53 toward nitro explosives. The dual-emission sensor with the incorporation of electron-enriched SG7 ions could promote the electron transfer and resonance energy transfer, resulting in the enhancement of the detection effect.
elements.clean_text: Compared with the results of FIR-53 in aqueous solution, SG7@FIR-53 shows a better detection effect. It is necessary to gain insights into the mechanism. The introduction of dye SG7 into FIR-53 could enhance the electron transfer from electron donors to analytes. Meanwhile, the existence of resonance energy transfer (RET) was considered by the method of UV-vis absorption. Because of the existence of SG7, the emission band FIR-53 is expanded from 450 to 520 nm. It further enlarges the extent of overlap between the emission spectrum of SG7@FIR-53 and the absorption spectrum of the acceptor (analytes). The absorption spectrum of TNP has a maximum overlap with the emission spectrum of SG7@FIR-53. Especially, 2-NP, 3-NP, and 4-NP have the larger overlap degree of spectra between nitro explosives and SG7@FIR-53 (Figure S42). The fact reveals that the RET may dominate the high sensitivity of SG7@FIR-53 toward nitro explosives. The dual-emission sensor with the incorporation of electron-enriched SG7 ions could promote the electron transfer and resonance energy transfer, resulting in the enhancement of the detection effect.

elements.content: Making full use of high crystallization and spatial confinement of MOFs, a dual-emission composite SG7@FIR-53 was prepared via SC–SC pathway. The single-crystal structure provides direct evidence of where the packing of pyrene molecules achieve the bright excimer emission, consistent with the theoretical simulation. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a metal–organic framework, which incorporates dye ions via SC–SC approach, to be obtaining the host–guest single-crystal structure. The composite SG7@FIR-53 exhibits a sensitive quenching response against Cr2O7 2– and MnO4 – in aqueous solution. Importantly, SG7@FIR-53 exhibits a broad quenching response against nitro explosives in vapor/aqueous phase. Compared with the results of FIR-53, the range and sensitivity was greatly improved. On the whole, these results demonstrate that incorporation of dye guests into MOFs to build a host–guest system opens a new way for the multiresponsive sensors with high sensitivity and selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Making full use of high crystallization and spatial confinement of MOFs, a dual-emission composite SG7@FIR-53 was prepared via SC-SC pathway. The single-crystal structure provides direct evidence of where the packing of pyrene molecules achieve the bright excimer emission, consistent with the theoretical simulation. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a metal-organic framework, which incorporates dye ions via SC-SC approach, to be obtaining the host-guest single-crystal structure. The composite SG7@FIR-53 exhibits a sensitive quenching response against Cr2O7 2- and MnO4 - in aqueous solution. Importantly, SG7@FIR-53 exhibits a broad quenching response against nitro explosives in vapor/aqueous phase. Compared with the results of FIR-53, the range and sensitivity was greatly improved. On the whole, these results demonstrate that incorporation of dye guests into MOFs to build a host-guest system opens a new way for the multiresponsive sensors with high sensitivity and selectivity.

cln_elements.content:
The crystal sample [Zn2(tipa)2(OH–)]­(NO3 –)3·6H2O was synthesized according to the reported literature.

Preparation of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(tipa)<sub>2</sub>(OH<sup>–</sup>)]­(NO<sub>3</sub> <sup>–</sup>)­(SG7)<sub>2/3</sub>·5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>SG7@FIR-53</bold>)

The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (30 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 8 mL, 4 × 10–3 mol L–1 solution of SG7 and kept for 1 month. The vials were shaken once a day. The dye-nitrate exchange process was monitored by UV–vis abosrption; the value of UV–vis abosrption remained unchanged when the process reached the dynamic equilibrium. After decanting the solution, the green-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air. EA, calcd for C62H55N15O15S2Zn2: C, 53.15; H, 3.80; N, 14.53%; found: C, 52.96; H, 4.01; N, 14.07%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn2(tipa)2(OH-)](NO3 -)3⋅6H2O (FIR-53)

The crystal sample [Zn2(tipa)2(OH-)](NO3 -)3⋅6H2O was synthesized according to the reported literature. 

Preparation of [Zn2(tipa)2(OH-)](NO3 -)(SG7)2/3⋅5H2O (SG7@FIR-53)

The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (30 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 8 mL, 4 × 10-3 mol L-1 solution of SG7 and kept for 1 month. The vials were shaken once a day. The dye-nitrate exchange process was monitored by UV-vis abosrption; the value of UV-vis abosrption remained unchanged when the process reached the dynamic equilibrium. After decanting the solution, the green-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air. EA, calcd for C62H55N15O15S2Zn2: C, 53.15; H, 3.80; N, 14.53%; found: C, 52.96; H, 4.01; N, 14.07%.

metadata.title:
Dual-Emission
SG7@MOF Sensor via SC–SC Transformation: Enhancing the Formation
of Excimer Emission and the Range and Sensitivity of Detection
